newsitem.title: SWEDEN: VOLVO SAYS NO DEAL ON MITSUBISHI MOTOR.
newsitem.headline: VOLVO SAYS NO DEAL ON MITSUBISHI MOTOR.

text.p: Swedish vehicle maker AB Volvo on Friday denied a report that it had signed an accord with Mitsubishi Motors Corp relating to its GDI engines for cars produced at its Dutch joint venture.
"The report that we have reached a contract is not right. No contract has yet been signed, but discussions are continuing in a positive spirit," Volvo Car spokesman Ingmar Hesslefors told Reuters.

Japanese economic daily Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported that Volvo had agreed to buy Mitsubishi's gasoline direct injection (GDI) engines and that Volvo would start selling passenger cars equipped with them from late 1997.
"The motor will be fitted in Mitsubishi's Galant model starting in the autumn but still not in any model produced in Europe," Hesslefors said.
Volvo said last month that talks were in progress about purchasing the engine for its four cylinder S40/V40, but that cost would prohibit it from becoming a standard feature.
Volvo produces its S40/V40 models in the NedCar Netherlands plant in Born.
Mitsubishi has said that its GDI engine uses 35 percent less fuel than its predecessor, while reducing carbon dioxide emissions by 35 percent and increasing engine power by 10 percent.
-- Henrik Alberius, Stockholm newsroom +46-8-700 1017 (c) Reuters Limited 1996
